elements.title: Part I Item 1. Business. Overview

data.value: Wheeler Real Estate Investment Trust, Inc. is a Maryland corporation formed on June 23, 2011.

The Trust serves as the general partner of Wheeler REIT, L.P., a Virginia limited partnership formed on April 5, 2012. As of December 31, 2022, 99.05% of the Operating Partnership is owned by the Company.

On August 22, 2022, the Company completed a merger transaction with Cedar Realty Trust, Inc. In the transaction, all outstanding shares of Cedar’s common stock were acquired, cancelled and converted into the right to receive a cash payment of $9.48 per share. Cedar’s 7.25% Series B Preferred Stock and 6.50% Series C Preferred Stock continue to trade on the NYSE, and Cedar became a subsidiary of the REIT.

The Company is a fully-integrated, self-managed commercial real estate investment company focused on owning, leasing and operating income-producing retail properties, primarily grocery-anchored centers.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Commitments and Contingencies, Tax Protection Agreement, Related Party Transactions, and Subsequent Events

data.value: Infrastructure development financed by bonds; future total principal obligation capped at $2.04 million as of December 31, 2022; potential interest obligations based on principal balance and LIBOR rates.
Company funded approximately $42K in 2022 and $87K in 2021 in debt service shortfalls with no accrual recorded as of December 31, 2022.

data.key: Acquisition of Harbor Pointe Associates, LLC
data.value: Harbor Pointe Associates, LLC, formerly owned by an affiliate of former CEO Jon Wheeler, was acquired by the Company in 2014.

In 2016, in connection with the acquisition of Berkley, Sangaree and Tri-County, the Operating Partnership entered an agreement to reimburse former CEO Jon Wheeler for tax liabilities triggered by recognition of certain taxable income or gain, with no liability recorded as of December 31, 2022.

Cedar, a subsidiary, paid $1.05 million for property management and leasing services during 2022; related party amounts of $7.33 million, primarily tied to financing costs and other expenses, were eliminated in consolidation.
The Company reimbursed the Stilwell Group for solicitation-related expenses, recording $369K in 2021, with full reimbursement completed by year-end 2021.
On February 21, 2023, the Company purchased a 2.5 acre land parcel in St. George, SC for $160K.

elements.title: Leadership and Executive Appointment Details

data.value: Mr. Franklin is responsible for overseeing property management, lease administration, and leasing divisions for the commercial assets portfolio. Previously, he was a partner at Broad Reach Retail Partners managing day-to-day operations, including asset, property and construction management for a portfolio totaling $50 million. He holds a Bachelor of Science in Finance from the University of Maryland.

Crystal Plum, age 41, was appointed as Chief Financial Officer (CFO) in February 2020. Prior to her current role, she served as Vice President of Financial Reporting and Corporate Accounting (March 2018 - February 2020) and as Director of Financial Reporting (September 2016 - March 2018). She also held managerial roles at Dixon Hughes Goodman LLP, and is a Certified Public Accountant with a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration - Accounting and Finance from Old Dominion University.
As of December 31, 2022, the company has 47 full-time employees.

The company offers competitive wage and benefit programs, including medical insurance, wellness programs, short and long term disability insurance, basic life insurance with accidental death and dismemberment, employee assistance programs, gym memberships, volunteer time off, and tuition assistance (including language learning opportunities).

The company aims to provide attractive risk-adjusted returns to its stockholders with strategies focusing on necessity-based retail, secondary/tertiary markets, optimized lease management (including triple net lease arrangements), and targeted capital investments in retail properties.

elements.title: Table of Contents Wheeler Real Estate Investment Trust, Inc. and Subsidiaries - Notes to Consolidated and Combined Financial Statements

data.value: The document includes a continuation of the note on consolidation, indicating that control is determined if the company has greater than 50% of the voting rights directly or indirectly.

The Company records investment properties and related intangibles at fair value upon acquisition, capitalizing improvements and major repairs that extend useful life, increase capacity or improve efficiency.

The purchase price of acquisitions is allocated to various components such as buildings, land, and intangible assets with fair value determined by observable or unobservable inputs; third party valuation specialists may be utilized.

Buildings and improvements are depreciated using the straight-line method over an estimated 5 to 40 years while tenant improvements and lease intangibles are amortized over the term of related leases.

Investment properties are reviewed for impairment when events suggest that carrying values may not be recoverable; impairment is measured when estimated undiscounted future operating income plus residual value is less than the carrying value.

This table presents detailed property information for retail/commercial properties managed by two entities: WHLR and CDR. The data includes property locations, occupancy rates, tenant counts, and financial metrics. Key findings include high lease and occupancy rates, aggregated square footage details, and annualized base rent values.
1,006 properties; 8,172,527 total square feet; 92.9% lease rate; 90.4% occupancy; 7,384,871 square feet occupied; Annualized metric of $73,240; additional notes on lease execution and adjustments.

elements.title: Major Tenants, Lease Expirations & Property Management Strategy

data.value: The table presents the top ten largest tenants in the operating portfolio as of December 31, 2022. Food Lion is the largest tenant with an annualized base rent of approximately $4.4M and 549,000 sqft occupied. Other key tenants include Kroger Co, Dollar Tree, Piggly Wiggly, and Planet Fitness, among others. Total annualized base rent across these tenants is about $17M, representing 23.19% of the portfolio with an average rent per sqft of $7.64.

The lease expiration schedule table outlines lease expirations by period from 'Available' through 2032 and thereafter. The portfolio comprises 1,006 leases covering 8.17 million sqft with total annualized base rent of $73.24M. Notably, 2025 shows the highest occupied square footage at 14.71% and annualized base rent of approximately $11.8M, with near-term expirations in 2023 and 2024 representing around 17% of the total square footage.

The document states that property management and leasing activities are self-administered, covering leasing, legal, acquisitions, development, data processing, finance, and accounting functions along with on-site management.

elements.title: Cash Flow Activities Comparison 2021-2022

data.value: Our cash flows from operating activities were $30.76 million and $17.04 million during the year ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, representing an increase of 80.49% or $13.72 million.

Our cash flows used in investing activities were $133.51 million during the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to cash flows from investing activities of $5.10 million during the year ended December 31, 2021, representing a decrease of (2,717.37)% or $138.61 million.

Our cash flows from financing activities were $118.20 million during the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to cash flows used in financing activities of $24.49 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, respectively, representing an increase of 582.63% or $142.69 million.

data.value: Wheeler Real Estate Investment Trust, Inc. and Subsidiaries

The statement shows an improved net loss (-8470K vs -9351K) and increased operating cash flow (30758K vs 17041K). Significant investing cash outflow (-133512K) primarily due to property acquisitions was offset by strong financing cash inflow (118200K), leading to an improved overall cash position.

elements.title: Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) – Assets Held for Sale, Asset Retirement Obligations, Cash & Receivables

data.value: Recorded at the lower of carrying value or fair value less estimated costs to sell. If carrying value exceeds fair value less costs, an impairment expense is recognized.
Estimates based on Level 2 (quoted prices for similar assets) and Level 3 (unobservable inputs) inputs from similar real estate sales.
No conditional asset retirement obligations recorded as of December 31, 2022 and 2021.
Highly liquid investments with an original maturity of 90 days or less, carried at cost which approximates fair value; primarily include bank operating accounts and money markets.
Amounts held for real estate taxes, insurance, capital improvements, leasing costs, and tenant security deposits, placed in FDIC-insured financial institutions.
Includes base rents, tenant reimbursements, and straight-lined rent receivables with an allowance for uncollectible amounts; allowances totaled $3.15 million for 2022 and $633 thousand for 2021.

elements.title: Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued)

data.key: Above and Below Market Lease Intangibles, net
data.value: Determined upon acquiring a property; amortized over the life of the leases and recorded as a component of rental revenues.

data.key: Deferred Costs and Other Assets, net
data.value: Consists primarily of leasing commissions, leases in place, capitalized legal and marketing costs, tenant relationships, and ground lease sandwich interest intangibles. Amortized on a straight‐line basis over lease terms, recorded as a component of depreciation and amortization expense.
Received proceeds of $552 thousand pursuant to the PPP under the CARES Act. The promissory note was forgiven during the year ended December 31, 2021 and recorded as 'other income'.

The Company does not use derivatives to hedge exposures; evaluates all financial instruments for embedded derivatives. Liability-accounted derivatives are recorded at fair value with revaluations based on Level 3 inputs.
Costs incurred in connection with raising funds are either paid in cash or equity, and are amortized to interest expense. These are presented as a direct deduction from the related debt liability.

The Company combines lease and nonlease components in contracts. Minimum rents are accrued on a straight-line basis leading to an unbilled rent asset. As of December 31, 2022, unbilled rent was $6.52 million compared to $5.77 million in 2021.

elements.title: Dividend Policy Changes

data.key: Suspension of Dividends on Common Stock
data.value: In March 2018, the Board of Directors suspended the payment of dividends on our Common Stock.
The Board of Directors also suspended the quarterly dividends on shares of our Series A, B, and D Preferred Stock beginning December 31, 2018.
Dividends were suspended to retain cash flow to pay operating expenses and reduce debt.

data.key: Impact on Series D Preferred Stock
data.value: Failed to pay cash dividends on Series D Preferred resulted in an increased annual dividend rate to 10.75% starting January 1, 2019.
On November 3, 2021, common stockholders voted to amend the charter to remove cumulative dividend rights of Series A and B Preferred.

elements.title: Dividend Suspension on Series D Preferred

data.value: The Company has suspended dividends on the Series D Preferred and therefore no dividends may be declared or paid on Common Stock or other preferred until the suspended amount is paid in full.
The Company does not intend to pay dividends other than those required to maintain REIT status.
COVID-19 has significantly impacted rent collections and could lead to increased tenant bankruptcies.
Acquisition of Cedar Realty Trust consummated on August 22, 2022.

elements.title: Preferred Dividend Policy Changes and Redemption Details

data.value: The Board suspended dividend payments for Series A Preferred, Series B Preferred, and Series D Preferred starting with Q4 2018.
On November 3, 2021, common stockholders approved amendments to remove the cumulative dividend feature for Series A and Series B Preferred.

data.key: Redemption Terms for Series D Preferred
data.value: After September 21, 2023, Series D Preferred Holders may require redemption at $25.00 per share plus accrued dividends, payable in cash, common stock, or a combination.

data.key: Dividend Accrual on Series D Preferred
data.value: Since January 2019, Series D Preferred accrues dividends at 10.75% per annum on a $25.00 liquidation preference, equating to $2.6875 per share per annum.

As of December 31, 2022, the Series D Preferred had an aggregate liquidation preference of approximately $78.81 million and accrued dividends of approximately $34.63 million, totaling $113.44 million. Estimated values on the Redemption Date are approximately $119.80 million.

data.key: Convertible Feature of Series D Preferred
data.value: Series D Preferred is convertible into common stock at a conversion price of $16.96 per share, though conversion is considered unlikely before the Redemption Date.
The company conducted two modified Dutch auction tender offers (December 2020 and April 2021) for Series D Preferred shares.

Interest payments on Convertible Notes were made in the form of Series D Preferred (December 2021) and Series B Preferred (June 2022), with values determined using volume-weighted average prices and a factor of 0.55.
The actions taken were intended to support liquidity needs and improve the Company's capital structure.

elements.title: Dividends Reference
Capital Structure Management and Asset Integration Strategy

data.value: Recycling and sensible management of capital structure. The company intends to sell non-income producing land parcels and use the sales proceeds to deleverage the balance sheet. In 2022, two properties were sold for a total of $10.51 million net proceeds which were used to reduce outstanding indebtedness. Additional dispositions may be considered based on periodic portfolio reviews and Board approval.

Strategy for integrating Cedar Assets through software and personnel integrations aimed at increasing scale and maximizing efficiencies at both the property and corporate level. The acquisition complements the existing portfolio by diversifying tenant credit profiles and micro-market risks.

The properties are subject to a variety of federal, state, and local environmental, health, safety, tax, and similar laws. Compliance has not had a material adverse effect on financial condition or operations.

The report outlines risks including competition from other developers and online retailers, potential impacts from natural or severe weather events, and cybersecurity threats affecting information systems.

elements.title: Loans Payable (continued) – Financing Agreements and Warrants

data.value: Option to redeem at 100% of principal plus accrued and unpaid interest; can be paid in cash, shares of Common Stock, or combination.

Entered on December 22, 2020 with Powerscourt Investments XXII, LP. The Company issued a warrant to purchase 496,415 shares of Common Stock at $3.12 per share. Registration rights agreement executed; the resale was registered on Form S-11 effective May 25, 2021. The $25.00 million financing was paid in full on March 12, 2021. The related warrant and registration rights agreement remain in effect as of December 31, 2022.

Entered on March 12, 2021 as borrower with various subsidiaries and guarantors. Provided a term loan of $35.00 million at an 8.00% rate, maturing in March 2026 with quarterly interest-only payments starting April 15, 2021. Principal repayments incur a premium of 5% (totaling $1.75 million). The financing is secured by liens, including mortgages on properties. Covenants restrict further indebtedness, asset disposals, equity issuances, and other transactions. A warrant to purchase a total of 1,061,719 shares is issued, exercisable from March 12, 2021 until the loan's maturity. A registration rights agreement was executed with the warrant holders, with registration on Form S-11 effective May 25, 2021. The principal balance was fully paid on December 21, 2021.
Referenced as Amendment 50 at the end of the note.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - Loans Payable (continued)

data.key: Fourth Amendment - First National Bank Loan
data.value: On September 22, 2021, extended the $875K First National Bank Loan to August 15, 2023 with monthly principal and interest payments of $25K. Interest is LIBOR plus 350 basis points with a minimum rate of 4.25%. Principal was paid in full under the Guggenheim Loan Agreement on June 17, 2022.

On September 22, 2021, extended the $1.31M Lumber River Loan to September 10, 2023 with monthly principal and interest payments of $11K. It bears interest at LIBOR plus 350 basis points with a minimum interest rate of 4.25%. Principal was paid in full via the Guggenheim Loan Agreement on June 17, 2022.
On February 2, 2021, refinanced the Tuckernuck Loan for $5.15M at an interest rate of 5.00%. The loan matures on March 1, 2026 with monthly principal and interest payments of $32K.

On May 28, 2021, extended the maturity of the Rivergate Loan with Synovus Bank from April 21, 2021 to October 20, 2021 with monthly principal payments of $60K plus accrued interest. A $3.54M principal payment was made on August 31, 2021 in conjunction with an outparcel sale. On September 30, 2021, refinanced the loan for $18.50M at 4.25% interest; the loan matures on September 30, 2031 with structured payment adjustments beginning in September 2026.

data.key: Columbia Fire Station Loan Forbearance and Payoff
data.value: On January 21, 2021, entered into a Forbearance Agreement with Pinnacle Bank at an interest rate of 14% and made a $500K principal payment, extending the loan’s maturity to July 21, 2021. The loan was paid in full on July 21, 2021.
On March 25, 2021, made a $3.22M principal payment on the Berkley/Sangaree/Tri-County loan, funded by the sale of the Berkley Shopping Center, along with $687K in defeasance.

On May 5, 2021, refinanced the JANAF Bravo Loan for $6.00M at an interest rate of 5.00%. The loan matures on May 5, 2024 with monthly principal and interest payments of $35K. The principal was subsequently paid in full under the JANAF Loan Agreement on July 6, 2022.

elements.title: Loans Payable and Refinancing Activities

data.value: Company made a $1.79 million principal paydown on the Walnut Hill Plaza loan and paid the remaining balance of $1.34 million on February 17, 2022, in connection with the sale of the property.

On June 17, 2022, the Company entered into a term loan for $75.00 million at a fixed rate of 4.25% with interest-only monthly payments; principal and interest payments based on a 30-year amortization schedule will commence on August 10, 2027. Proceeds were used to refinance eleven loans including a $1.46 million defeasance payment.

On July 6, 2022, the Company secured a $60.00 million loan from CITI Real Estate Funding Inc. at a fixed rate of 5.31%, with interest-only monthly payments through maturity on July 6, 2032. Proceeds refinanced three loans with $1.16 million in defeasance.

On August 22, 2022, a $130.00 million loan was entered into with KeyBank National Association. It featured interest-only monthly payments through maturity on August 22, 2023, and an interest rate comprising the Secured Overnight Financing Rate plus 0.10% and an adjustable margin. The obligations were later satisfied using proceeds from subsequent loan agreements.

On October 28, 2022, the Company secured a $110.00 million loan at a fixed rate of 5.25% with interest-only monthly payments until November 2027. Wheeler REIT, L.P. provided a guarantee. From December 10, 2027, principal and interest payments will be made on a 30-year amortization schedule; the proceeds refinanced a portion of Cedar’s property portfolio.
On December 9, 2022, the Company made a $5.64 million principal payment on the Butler Square loan associated with the sale of the Butler Square property.

On December 21, 2022, a $25.00 million loan was entered into with CITI Real Estate Funding, Inc. at a fixed rate of 6.35%, with interest-only monthly payments through maturity on January 6, 2033. Proceeds were used to satisfy remaining obligations of the KeyBank-Cedar Loan Agreement and release collateral.

elements.title: CAUTIONARY STATEMENT ON FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS

data.value: Wheeler Real Estate Investment Trust, Inc.
Annual Report Form 10-K Forward-Looking Statements Disclosure

This section contains forward-looking statements that are based on management’s current expectations and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. It warns investors that actual future results may differ materially due to various factors.

COVID-19 pandemic and future infectious disease outbreaks; economic and retail market conditions; tenant bankruptcies; dilution of common stock; litigation risks; interest rate changes; challenges in integrating acquisitions (e.g., Cedar Realty Trust, Inc.); natural disasters and climate change; IT security breaches; and risks related to maintaining REIT qualification and tax status.
May, will, should, potential, predicts, anticipates, expects, intends, plans, believes, seeks, estimates, and their negatives.
No obligation to update or revise forward-looking statements even if assumptions change or events occur.

elements.title: Risk Factors and Forward-Looking Statements

data.value: The impact of e-commerce on our tenants’ business
Inability to generate sufficient cash flows due to market conditions, competition, uninsured losses, changes in tax or other applicable laws
Forward-looking statements should be read in light of these factors

elements.title: Risk Disclosure: Cybersecurity, Insurance, and Reporting Requirements

data.value: The company acknowledges that despite multiple measures to prevent and mitigate threats, there is no guarantee that a cyber attack will be prevented. A successful attack could compromise confidential information and disrupt business operations.

The company carries comprehensive liability, fire, extended coverage, business interruption, rental loss, and additional coverages including trademark and pollution insurance, as well as directors’ and officers’ liability insurance. However, these policies may not fully cover all losses resulting from cybersecurity breaches.

The company is subject to information reporting requirements under the Exchange Act and provides access to its annual report, quarterly reports, and other filings via the SEC website and its own website. The content on the website is not incorporated by reference into official reports.
The disclosures relate to potential risks from cybersecurity breaches, limitations of insurance coverage, and the absence of any known security breaches in the past two years.

elements.title: Convertible Notes Interest, Series D Preferred Redemption, and Economic Risk Factors

data.value: On January 3, 2023, interest on Convertible Notes was paid in Series B Preferred; each share valued based on a volume-weighted average price multiplied by 0.55.

Initiated on November 22, 2022 to address Series D Preferred redemption risk; condition required 66 2/3% of outstanding shares tendered and consented, but only 26.8% (864,391 shares) were received by January 20, 2023, leading to offer expiration.

Failure to meet redemption conditions means Series D Preferred remains outstanding. Future redemption of Series D Preferred may force redemption settlement in Common Stock, causing substantial dilution.

Discussion on inflation, deflation, and interest rate increases impacting operations. Although lease provisions partially mitigate inflation impacts, prolonged changes may result in material adverse effects.
Reference to related recent Accounting Pronouncements in Note 2 of the consolidated financial statements (page 38 of the Annual Report on Form 10-K).

elements.title: Commitments and Contingencies – Regulatory and Environmental; Litigation

data.value: The Company faces potential liability for hazardous materials (e.g., asbestos, lead) and adverse building conditions, which may result in fines, remediation expenses, and impact tenant rental payments.
David Kelly filed suit alleging breach of his employment contract. The court awarded $340K plus fees; $691K was paid, fulfilling the Company's obligations.

Multiple related suits alleging violation of charter provisions regarding Series D Preferred and securities law violations. Proceedings include denial of motions to dismiss, discovery schedules, mediation orders, and a settlement agreement among some parties.

elements.title: Commitments and Contingencies - Litigation and Other Commitments

data.value: On November 3, 2022, the Stipulation of Dismissal was filed, dismissing with prejudice all of the JCP Plaintiffs’ claims against the Company.

In the case involving Steamboat Capital Partners Master Fund, LP and Steamboat Capital Partners II, LP, summary judgment was concluded in the Company's favor on September 20, 2022, with plaintiffs not appealing.

Multiple related lawsuits regarding Cedar Realty Trust, Inc. include a putative class action (Case No.: 1:22-cv-1103) alleging breach of contract and fiduciary duty, with a consolidated amended complaint and uncertain litigation outcomes.
A putative class action was filed on October 14, 2022, in Nassau, New York, alleging similar claims as in the Cedar litigation, with procedural motions pending and uncertain outcome.

A complaint was filed by a purported holder of the Company's preferred stock alleging violations of Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and SEC Rule 10b-5, with a motion to dismiss granted; outcome remains uncertain.

On September 1, 2011, the Grove Economic Development Authority issued a Tax Increment Revenue Note for $2.42 million at a variable interest rate of 2.29%, payable in 50 semi-annual installments, intended to fund economic projects.

elements.title: Ranking and Events of Default for Notes

data.value: subordinate and junior in right of payment
Obligations to holders of senior indebtedness paid in full before Notes

1. Failure to pay principal or premium; 2. Failure to pay interest installment; 3. Failure to provide notice for conversion or redemption; 4. Compliance failure with terms of Notes or Indenture; 5. Voluntary insolvency of the Company or subsidiaries; 6. Involuntary insolvency if unstayed for 60 days.
Trustee or holders of at least 25% principal amount may declare Notes due and payable.
Requires written consent of majority holders to amend or supplement Indenture or Notes.

elements.title: Provisions Modification Details

data.value: The ranking provisions of the Indenture relative to other indebtedness could be modified in a manner adverse to the holders.
The percentage in the aggregate principal amount of Outstanding Notes whose holders must consent to a modification or amendment could be reduced.
The percentage for a waiver of compliance or Default could be reduced.
The provisions regarding modification and waiver cannot be modified except to increase the percentage required for modification or waiver.
